properties.name: Snakeiana Jones
properties.description: An example of a basic platformer (Mario-like) game. Jump around and collect as many coins as you can!
properties.author: Farol Neon

objects.name: EndScreenBestText
objects.string: You got the highest number of points!

events.comment:
This tab is the event sheet, which defines the logic of the game.
Some objects have behaviors that also perform logic and you can learn about those by reveiwing the extensions in this project.
Note: Keyboard controls are provided by the Platformer behavior automatically
Only move the player when the joystick is moved 40% away from center
Make button darker when pressed

events.name: Change animation based on what player is doing

events.comment: Trigger the sound and particle emitter on the 4th and 14th frame of the walking animation (to simulate footstep)
Save the position of the player at the beginning of the scene as the first checkpoint
If the player collides with the checkpoint object and it is not active this will trigger
Reset all checkpoints. "Pick all" is required because the collision condition only picks the checkpoint touching the player.
Activate the checkpoint that the player is touching
Detect player falling below the screen
If player is dead, move back to the last saved checkpoint position

events.name: GHOST AI - It follows when not looking at him

events.comment: Flip when player is behind the ghost, and add movement force when player is not looking
Looking at the player (Player flipped, Ghost not flipped)
If player falls on enemy then enemy is defeated
Make player bounce up from fly (using a jump)
Update score
Disable the behavior that moved the fly up and down, add a downward force (90 degrees = down) and make fly rotate back and forth
When a Fly falls below background it is deleted. (This is just a good house keeping practice)
Start a Timer when the mush guy start to pop up and when to shoot
GETTING UP
SHOOTING PEA
If player falls on enemy then enemy is defeated
Otherwise, the player is defeated
Player always dies if the fire animation is showing

events.name: Use a  timer to set a boolean variable

events.comment: Timers must be started with an action

events.name: Change animation based on that boolean variable

events.comment: Start the game with the "EndScreen" layer hidden and make the overlay semi-transparent
Detect when the player reaches the door
Stop controlling player movement with platformer behavior and then use tweens to animate the player falling into the portal
Shrink player
Display appropriate text based on player score
Center objects and resize the overlay to cover entire screen
Animate text when mouse hovers over it
Restart the scene
Boundary objects act like invisible walls for the player and they also define where the camera can move.
Background motion (parallax) and adjust size to fit screen
Increase volume of portal as the player gets closer

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: @4ian, Tristan Rhodes (https://victrisgames.itch.io/)
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: EllipseMovement
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Move objects on ellipses or smoothly back and forth in one direction.
description: It allows objects to move:
- on an ellipsis or arcs
- smoothly vertically or horizontally (by setting one radius to 0)
- on a sine wave (by adding a force)
It can be used for:
- Making objects float, such as powerups or coins
- Moving platforms
- Enemy movement patterns
- Making a player constantly turn right or left ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://star-seeker))

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Move objects on ellipses or smoothly back and forth in one direction.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: EllipseMovement

events.comment: Evaluate the center of movement from the object position and properties.
Update the center when the object is moved outside of the behavior.
Place the object according to the movement angle.
Save the position to detect when the object is moved outside of the behavior.
Update the movement angle for the next frame.

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: SmoothCamera
eventsFunctionsExtensions.previewIconUrl: https://resources.gdevelop-app.com/assets/Icons/Line Hero Pack/Master/SVG/Computers and Hardware/Computers and Hardware_camcoder_gopro_go_pro_camera.svg
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Smoothly scroll to follow an object.
description: The camera follows an object according to:
- a frame rate independent catch-up speed to make the scrolling from smooth to strong
- a maximum speed to do linear following or slow down the camera when teleporting the object
- a follow-free zone to avoid scrolling on small movements
- an offset to see further in one direction
- an extra delay and catch-up speed to give an impression of speed (useful for dash)
- position forecasting and delay to simulate a cameraman response time
A platformer dedicated behavior allows to switch of settings when the character is in air or on the floor. This can be used to stabilize the camera when jumping.

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Smoothly scroll to follow an object.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: SmoothCamera

events.comment: Update private properties through setters to check their values and initialize state.

Delaying and forecasting can be used at the same time.
Forecasting only use the positions that are older than the one used for delaying.
The behavior uses a position history that is split in 2 arrays:
- one for delaying the position (from TimeFromStart to TimeFromStart - CamearDelay)
- one for forecasting the position (from TimeFromStart - CamearDelay to TimeFromStart - CamearDelay - ForecastHistoryDuration

At each frame, the camera must catchup the target by a given ratio (speed)
cameraX(t) - targetX = (cameraX(t - 1) - targetX) * speed

The frame rate must not impact on the catch-up speed, we don't want a speed in ratio per frame but a speed ratio per second, like this:
cameraX(t) - targetX = (cameraX(t - 1s) - targetX) * speed

Ok, but we still need to process each frame, we can use a exponent for this:
cameraX(t) - targetX = (cameraX(t - timeDelta) - targetX) * speed^timeDelta
cameraX(t) = targetX + (cameraX(t - timeDelta) - targetX) * exp(timeDelta * ln(speed))

pow is probably more efficient than precalculated log if the speed is changed continuously but this might be rare enough.

eventsFunctions.description: Delay the camera according to a maximum speed and catch up the delay.

eventsFunctions.sentence: Delay the camera of _PARAM0_ during: _PARAM2_ seconds according to the maximum speed _PARAM3_;_PARAM4_ seconds and catch up in _PARAM5_ seconds

eventsFunctions.description: Update delayed position and delayed history. This is called in doStepPreEvents.
eventsFunctions.name: UpdateDelayedPosition
eventsFunctions.sentence: Update delayed position and delayed history of _PARAM0_

events.comment: Add the previous position to have enough (2) positions to evaluate the extra delay for waiting mode.
Use the object center when no delay is asked.
Remove history entries that are too old to be useful for delaying and pass it to the history for forecasting.
Don't move the camera if there is not enough history.

Add the extra delay that could be needed to respect the speed limit in waiting mode.

speedRatio = min(speedMaxX / historySpeedX, speedMaxY / historySpeedY)
delay += min(0, timeDelta * (1 - speedRatio))
The time with delay is now between the first 2 indexes

events.comment:
Remove history entries that are too old to be useful.
Keep at least 2 positions because no forecast can be done with less positions.

eventsFunctions.description: Update forecasted position. This is called in doStepPreEvents.
eventsFunctions.name: UpdateForecastedPosition

events.comment:
Simple linear regression
y = A * x + B

A = Covariance / VarianceX
B = MeanY - A * MeanX

Note than we could use only one position every N positions to reduce the process time,
but if we really need efficient process JavaScript and circular queues are a must.

VarianceX = sum((X[i] - MeanX))
VarianceY = sum((Y[i] - MeanY))
Covariance = sum((X[i] - MeanX) * (Y[i] - MeanY))

y = A * x + B

A = Covariance / VarianceX
B = MeanY - A * MeanX
Axis permutation to avoid a ratio between 2 numbers near 0.
Permute back axis

eventsFunctions.description: Project history ends position to have the vector on the line from linear regression. This function is only called by UpdateForecastedPosition.
eventsFunctions.name: ProjectHistoryEnds
eventsFunctions.sentence: Project history oldest: _PARAM2_;_PARAM3_ and newest position: _PARAM4_;_PARAM5_ of _PARAM0_

events.comment:
Perpendicular line:
pA = -1/a; 
pB = -pA * x + y

Intersection:
/ ProjectedY = a * ProjectedX + b
\ ProjectedY = pA * ProjectedX + b

Solution that is cleaned out from indeterminism (like 0 / 0 or infinity / infinity):
ProjectedX= (x + (y - b) * a) / (a + 1)
ProjectedY = y + (x * a - y + b) / (a + 1)

eventsFunctions.description: Return the ratio between forecast time and the duration of the history. This function is only called by UpdateForecastedPosition.
eventsFunctions.name: ForecastTimeRatio

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: Elairyx, @Bouh
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: Checkpoints
description: Allows to set up checkpoints for each instance.
Checkpoint coordinates are dynamic values so can be object positions absolute/relative values and more.
Checkpoints can then be used to move the same or even other instances to them.

eventsFunctions.description: Update a checkpoint of an object.
eventsFunctions.name: SaveCheckpoint

eventsFunctions.description: Change the position of the object to the saved checkpoint.
eventsFunctions.name: LoadCheckpoint

parameters.longDescription: Loading not yet saved checkpoints will (by default) set the position to the coordinate 0;0. Select "yes" to completely ignore non-existant checkpoints. To define an alternative checkpoint for it, create a new event and use the "Checkpoint exists" condition, save the wanted checkpoint as the action.
parameters.name: SetIgnoreUndefined

eventsFunctions.description: Check if a checkpoint has a position saved / does exist.
eventsFunctions.name: CheckpointExist

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: Bouh
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: Gamepads
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Add support for gamepads (or other controllers) to your game, giving access to information such as button presses, axis positions, trigger pressure, etc...
description: Add support for gamepads (or other controllers) to your game, giving access to information such as button presses, axis positions, axis force, trigger pressure, deadzone for each gamepad, etc...
Up to 4 gamepads can be connected. For each condition or expression, you'll have to enter the index of the gamepad to read. This is 1, 2, 3 or 4.

eventsFunctions.description: Get the value of the pressure on a gamepad trigger.

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: MultitouchJoystick
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Activate a joystick or buttons that can be controlled by interacting with a touchscreen.
description: Users can interact with the multitouch joystick to specify angle and force values.  These values can be used to control other objects in the scene such as movement and rotation, such as for twin-stick shooter games.
Mulitouch buttons can be used whenever a game allows the user to press multiple locations at once.
How to use:
- Add the joystick behavior to a sprite that will be the joystick
- Place the joystick object on the scene
- Run the "Activate joystick" action on every frame and specify the thumb object
- The joystick thumb object will automatically be created and moved
Tips:
- Use "Simulate a touch" functions to provide mouse and gamepad controls
- More than one joystick or button can be used at the same time
- Joystick and thumb objects should have all sides the same length
- Thumb object must be smaller than the joystick object

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: @4ian, Tristan Rhodes (https://victrisgames.itch.io/)
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: RectangularMovement
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Allow an object to move in a rectangular pattern.
description: Allow an object to move in a rectangular pattern.
By default, movement will slow down when going around corners, but this can be changed to always use a constant speed.
Example uses:
- Moveable platforms
- Enemy movement patterns
Properties:
- Center of movement, X position
- Center of movement, Y position
- Horizontal distance
- Vertical distance
- Horizontal speed
- Vertical speed
- Use constant speed (object will not slow down at corners)
- Use counter-clockwise direction
Tips:
- Set the CenterX and CenterY values to move the object
- For horizontal movement only, set vertical distance to 0
- For vertical movement only, set horizontal distance to 0
- Use conditions to apply logic based on the direction the object is moving.  For example, setting the animation.

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: Tristan Rhodes (https://victrisgames.itch.io/)
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: ShakeObject
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Shake an object, using one or more ways to shake (position, angle, scale).
description: Select one or more methods of shaking:
- Position: Shake the X and/or Y position of the object
- Angle: Shake the angle (rotation) of the object
- Scale: Shake the scale of the object (must be a sprite)
Control how the object shakes:
- Amplitude: How far the object moves during each shake
- Duration: Amount of time to shake the object
- Time between shakes: Amount of time between each movement of the object
- Keep shaking until stopped (boolean)
Tips:
- For a single-shake effect, set the "Time between shakes" to be equal to "Duration"  (great for a hit or impact)
- To make the single-shake move in the opposite direction, use negative numbers
- To repeat a single-shake effect in a loop, add a condition "Object is not shaking"
- Use a long "Time between shakes" to simulate a slow moving object (like a ship rocking back and forth)
- Make sure to "Stop shaking" before starting a new shake if it uses different parameters.
- Use "Shake until stopped" to simulate engine vibration, earthquake, or pulsing
